results.title: Anthony Caro
results.creator_credit: Nigel Wattis, AM Productions and LWT
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Phaidon art collection”.
This documentary, presented and edited by Melvyn Bragg, presents the British artist Anthony Caro, famous for his ‘revolutionary’ approach to sculpture making in the 60’s. Initially training at the Royal Academy in London as a sculptor and then under the tutelage of Henry Moore, a disillusioned Caro made a trip to New York where he befriended the famous New York art critic, Clement Greenberg. The trip was to symbolise a radical shift in Caro’s approach to his art making, earning him his revolutionary status for criticisms that his work was, ‘crude and over simplified’. The documentary discusses Caro’s philosophy and methods over the decades and follows Caro in the process of constructing a number of steel sculptures. A prodigious artist with an output of over 2,000 sculptures whose search for, ‘the fact of the work and not the form’, makes this an exciting documentary about one of the modernist greats.

results.title: Ben Nicholson 1894-1982
results.creator_credit: John Read, Anne Balfour Fraser, Arts Council of Great Britain and RM Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Phaidon art collection”.
This is the story of the modern English artist Ben Nicholson as remembered by some of his closest friends and colleagues: Patrick Heron, Andras Kalman, Sir Leslie Martin, Angela Verren and Dr Felicitas Vogler. At the height of his career, Nicholson was one of the few artists to obtain international recognition with his contributions to modern art. His ‘white wall reliefs’ of the 30’s were his most notable work. This documentary traces his life and movements across Europe from Cumberland, St Ives to Switzerland - landscapes that were to influence his work greatly and remain a source of inspiration during his lifetime. Written and narrated by John Read.

results.title: Point counterpoint: the life and work of Georges Seurat 1859-1891
results.creator_credit: Ann Turner, BBC and RM Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Phaidon art collection”.
This documentary of Suerat not only addresses the man as artist and one of the most important of France in the late 19th Century but also of his person - a man of mystery, a revolutionary who was also both modest and self-effacing by nature. Combining both the impressionists love of light and colour with his own ‘scientific’ system for colour exploration Suerat welcomed the post-revolutionary era, and not unlike the Eiffel tower that became a symbol for modern France, Seurat was to symbolise the shift toward the modern in the art world. Written and narrated by David Thompson.

results.title: Hockney at the Tate
results.creator_credit: Alan Benson, RM Arts and South Bank Show
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Phaidon art collection”.
Melvyn Bragg interviews David Hockney in this relaxed documentary. Hockney walks through a major retrospective exhibition held at the Tate Gallery London in 1988, starting with his first oil painting, a painting of his father, through his student and early work to his contemporary return to painting. He talks of his move from England to Southern California where he painted his well known pools and splashes. His double portraiture is discussed as is his spatial experiments with composite photography. Hockney talks of his theatre design and his return to painting with his contemporary works featuring curves, bright colours and strange subjective perspectives. The sometimes witty and casual down to earth Hockney ends with a recent portrait of his mother. Edited and presented by Melvyn Bragg.

results.title: Max Ernst
results.creator_credit: Peter Schamoni, RM Arts and Zweites Deutsches Fernsehen
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Phaidon art collection”.
Traces the history of renowned painter and sculptor, Max Ernst, his personal life as well as artistic career. The program contains extensive interviews and commentary from Ernst himself which details the pattern of his life and work from his founding influence in the Surrealist movement, throughout World War II and his struggles within and without Germany up to his settlement in America and then move back to Europe. Opening with an outline of the commencement of the Dada movement in 1919, the program discusses the life history of Ernst from his move to Paris before World War II and his association and friendship with Paul Eluard along with other founding members of the Surrealist group. The details of his artistic interests in natural history made strange, that is, the confusion of disparate beings and objects in nature through mind and poetic associations, are discussed in terms of his public work as well as that undertaken in more personal spaces such as murals in friends houses and sculptures and exterior murals adorning his own various residences. With the advent of Hitler’s power in Germany, his works as a mirror to a ‘mad time’ are studied, along with the progress of Ernst away from the Surrealist movement before World War II. At the commencement of the war, a trying era began for Ernst of imprisonments at various stages in France for his German citizenship and as a result of false accusations, spending a few months in a concentration camp, which led to his subsequent difficult, but finally successful move to America with the help of colleague and third wife Peggy Guggenheim and the New York art scene. Here the program details his first Surrealist Exhibition in New York and his invention of what is now known as action painting, all received with great critical acclaim, and his following career in New York, during which time he married the painter, Dorothea Tanning. Their move to Arizona, to live and work in a ‘landscape of the minds eye’ signalled a time of detachment from many of his peers and a fascination with Native American culture and crafts and the rythms of the landscape that he had painted before seeing and that manifested a great influence in his works of the time. In the 1950s, his return to Europe was met with little recognition, but following the receipt of the Grand Prix of Venice in 1954, his acclaim saw an establishment of his freedom to experiment with his progression of interests in painting and sculpture once again. The program closes with an analysis of his work at this stage where his final settlement in the ‘Garden of France’ with Dorothea is discussed with reference to the hopeful nuances of his later series of paintings that studied the idea of the cage, and most symbolically, an empty cage from which a bird had escaped.

results.title: Marc Chagall
results.creator_credit: Kim Evans, LWT and RM Arts
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Phaidon art collection”.
At a time when the world was turning toward Modernism. artist Marc Chagall had decided to finally leave his native Russia for Paris, the epi-centre of the art world at the turn of the 20th Century. Having suffered a poor and repressed childhood as a Russian Jew marginalised by poverty and cultural dissent Chagall’s iconography differed from his contemporaries. Whilst employing essentially a cubist surface his subject matter was deeply personal drawing on his life experiences. This documentary explores Chagall’s personal vision as artist and storyteller charting his career through his paintings, set and costume designs and stain glass work. Edited and presented by Melvyn Bragg.

results.title: Donatello 1386-1466: the first modern sculptor
results.creator_credit: Ann Turner, BBC and RM Arts
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Phaidon art collection”.
Donatello is said in this documentary to be the most versatile and imaginative of all artists of his century and he is credited with bringing the Renaissance to Italy. The intense and personal work of Donatello is examined here in terms of his vision, emotion and techniques. Most notable is his inventive techniques in his work such as was used in his relief making sculpture. Writer and art historian Charles Avery locates an obscure terra-cotta relief of Donatello’s in Florence and throughout the documentary the authentication of the work is shown. Avery discusses the work of Donatello along with sculptors Henry Moore, Elisabeth Frink, and Peter Rockwell. This documentary was made shortly after the restoration of a number of significant works by Donatello and is the first time that these works can be seen in their former glory revealing a brilliance in colour and detail not seen in recent history.

results.title: Isamu Noguchi
results.creator_credit: Bruce W. Bassett and Whitgate Productions Ltd
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Phaidon art collection”.
Isamu Noguchi (1904-88) was one of the world’s leading sculptors of the 20th century. By rights American, residing in both Long Island and the Japanese island Shikoku, Noguchi throughout the documentary makes reference to his ‘nomadic’ life influenced by his family upbringing and this relationship to his work. Throughout the documentary, Noguchi explores his relationship with place, sculpture and stone (his chosen material) discussing freely his ideas and motivations. Some of his large scale commissions from the 60’s to the late 70’s are featured in locations as varied as Paris, Detroit, Japan and Mexico City along with the sets he designed for Martha Graham’s dance “Cortege of Eagles” (see 16mm film title #015721 of the same title). Written, directed and narrated by Bruce W. Bassett, this documentary features some iconic photography by Bruce G. Sparks that captures the spirit of the time reflecting the value of Noguchi’s legacy.

results.title: Quiet man with welding torch: a portrait of sculptor Julio Gonzalez 1876-1942
results.creator_credit: Laurence Boulting, William Leeson, Barrie Gavin, RM Arts and Waveband Film Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Phaidon art collection”.
The spanish artist Julio Gonzalez (1876-1942) has been recognised along with Brancusi and Picasso as one of the most important sculptors of the 20th Century in his generation responsible for ‘opening the most doors for 20th century sculpture’. A man of acute sensibilities whose ‘aesthetics of poverty’ gave birth to a legacy that celebrated found junk-metal and iron scraps making elegant and poignant sculptural forms. The documentary examines the sculptors past as jeweller and his growing aesthetic and technical methods throughout his career. A fearful man who lived a simple life away from publicity and the art world after the volatile period surrounding the world wars in Europe and the Spanish civil war. Narrated by Lyndon Brook.

results.title: Three colours Cezanne
results.creator_credit: Janice Sutherland, BBC and RM Arts
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Phaidon art collection”.
Cezanne is widely understood as “the father of modernism”. It was Cezanne’s studies of structure in the landscape that acted as a precursor to cubism and abstraction in the 20th Century. In his lifetime however he was much maligned by the critics and public alike and would often retreat into a rural solitary existence. His difficult relationship with his father and strained family life resulted in a lifelong struggle for happiness and determined much of his personal difficulties. This documentary details his ‘constant’ emotional struggles alongside his working career and draws on the observations of a number of contemporary artists and historians to help us understand how complex Cezanne’s life was to his art. Commentaries by: Bridget Riley, Howard Hodgkin, R.B. Kitaj, Joseph Rishal, critic John Golding and granddaughter, Aline Cezanne.
